abstract.original_text: The 2019 novel coronavirus (2019-nCoV) outbreak in Wuhan since December 2019 [1] has quickly spread to twenty-five countries [2], caused more than 44,000 cases and 1,000 deaths so far [3] . The fast sharing of 2019-nCoV genomes in GISAID (https://www.gisaid.org) provides a valuable dataset for 2019-nCoV haplotype network analysis, which is crucial for transmission and evolutionary track surveillance and secondary outbreak prevention.

sentences.segment_text: The 2019 novel coronavirus ( 2019-nCoV ) outbreak in Wuhan since December 2019 ( 1 ) has quickly spread to twenty-five countries ( 2 ) ,
caused more than 44,000 cases and 1,000 deaths so far ( 3 ) .
The fast sharing of 2019-nCoV genomes in GISAID ( https://www.gisaid.org ) provides a valuable dataset for 2019-nCoV haplotype network analysis ,
which is crucial for transmission and evolutionary track surveillance and secondary outbreak prevention .

abstract.original_text: We called single-nucleotide variations (SNVs) for all the 84 2019-nCov genomes in GISAID using MN908947 as the reference. Genomes with same SNVs are grouped into a haplotype

sentences.segment_text: We called single-nucleotide variations ( SNVs ) for all the 84 2019-nCov genomes in GISAID using MN908947 as the reference .
Genomes with same SNVs are grouped into a haplotype
